Extract sequences by id from FASTA: perl -ne 'if(/^>(\S+)/){$c=grep{/^$1$/}qw(id1 id2)}print if $c' file.fa
Fetch FASTA sequences using identifiers from a file. 'grep -A1 -f list fullfasta > fastaofidsfromlist'
go to previous directory "cd -"
FASTQ to FASTA: sed -n '1~4s/^@/>/p;2~4p' file.fq > file.fa
Run your last command as root: sudo !!
Learn how NOT to be a bioinformatician
Easy way to count 'N's in FASTA - using BioPython: fastaSequence.lower().count('n')
Don't let your bash scripts ignore failed commands, set -o errexit
In Perl 5.10, use ''say'' instead of ''print'' to avoid typing newlines. print 'Hello World!\n' == say 'Hello World!'
Lose your terminal? Try this command: reset
In R, use textxy in the calibrate package to label individual data points
Perl for one-liners in a pipe. Python for everything else.
Write beautiful Perl code. Use 'Perl Critic' and 'Perl Tidy'
^foo^bar - run the last command, but replace the first instance of foo with bar
#! - it's pronounced 'shebang'
Do you always type 'sl' instead of 'ls'? This will be fun: sudo apt-get install sl
split FASTQ file into 5 files to parallelize in the cluster. awk 'NR%4==1{ f=(FILENAME)"."(++i%5); }{ print >> f }' <fastq>
A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away: telnet towel.blinkenlights.nl
Split multi-FASTA file to indiv FASTA files: awk '/^>/{s=++d".fa"} {print > s}' multi.fa
All features types in GFF3: grep -v '^#' annotations.gff3 | cut -s -f 3 | sort | uniq

BAM -> FASTQ: samtools view file.bam | awk 'BEGIN {FS="	"} {print "@" $1 "
" $10 "
+
" $11}' > file.fq
Have you ever wanted a cow to say your output? sudo apt-get install cowsay && ls | cowsay
Don't know what is taking up all of your disk space? sudo apt-get install baobab && baobab
Secure as much as possible with Two Factor Authentication
To quickly look for all annotated SNPs in a gene or region, use the UCSC Table Browser
Ask before deleting files: alias rm="rm -i"
Create Venn Diagrams from lists of items (e.g. SNPs) with Venny or BioVenn
Top ten running processess sorted by memory: ps aux | sort -nk +4 | tail
